title: 11 Easy & Effective Ways to Build Strong Thigh Muscles

steps.title: The only equipment you’ll need is yourself.
steps.content: The only equipment you’ll need is yourself. Stand with your feet slightly wider than your hips, then engage your core to straighten your back. [2] X Expert Source Jason Whalen Certified Personal Trainer Expert Interview. 26 January 2021. Shift your hips backward as you slowly squat down without moving your feet. [3] X Expert Source Monica Morris Certified Personal Trainer Expert Interview. 18 November 2019. Lower yourself until your thighs are parallel to the floor, then slowly raise back up. [4] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Repeat your squat 8 to 10 times for one set. Slowly work your way up to doing 2 sets at a time. If you’re having trouble squatting all the way down, put a chair behind you. When your bum touches the chair, it’s time to rise back up. This exercise not only strengthens your thighs, but it helps your abs, hips, rear, calves, and shins, too.

steps.title: This will also give you a nice stretch in the back of your thighs.
steps.content: This will also give you a nice stretch in the back of your thighs. Stand with your feet underneath your hips, and your knees slightly bent. Lean forward, keeping your back straight until you feel a tightness in your hamstrings. Slowly raise back up to the starting position by pushing your feet forward. [5] X Research source Try 12 to 15 reps at first. If you’re having trouble keeping your back straight, put one hand on your lower back so you can feel how it moves and bends throughout the exercise. This exercise is also sometimes called a Romanian Deadlift.

steps.title: You can work these into your lower body workouts once or twice a week.
steps.content: You can work these into your lower body workouts once or twice a week. Start standing up straight with your feet directly underneath your hips. Step back with your right foot, bending both knees and lowering your right knee toward the ground. Pull yourself back into a standing position by engaging your glutes and your core. [6] X Research source Do 10 to 12 repetitions on your right leg before you switch to your left leg. Try to work up to doing 2 to 3 sets of lunges on each leg. If you’d like to increase the intensity of this workout, hold a dumbbell or a medicine ball in front of your chest.

steps.title: If you’ve been strength-training for a while, you may want to up the intensity.
steps.content: If you’ve been strength-training for a while, you may want to up the intensity. Get into a standing position with your feet underneath your hips. Place a weighted barbell on the floor in front of you, then sit into a deep squat with your back flat. Lean over at your hips, then grab the barbell and slowly raise it. Lift with your legs as you slowly get up into a standing position. [7] X Research source You can perform a deadlift as many times as you’re able to. The amount of weight on your barbell is up to you. If you’re starting, go lighter than you think you can handle.

steps.title: Make sure you work each part of the thigh for a 360-degree workout.
steps.content: Make sure you work each part of the thigh for a 360-degree workout. Lie on your right side, supporting your weight with your right forearm. Extend your right leg out in a straight line, then put your left foot on top of your right knee. Raise your right leg slightly off the floor and hold it in place for 3 to 5 seconds before lowering back down for one rep. [8] X Research source Do 15 reps on your right leg before switching to your left leg. If you’re having trouble balancing, place your left hand behind your head for extra stability.

steps.title: You can work your thighs, rear, and calves all at the same time.
steps.content: You can work your thighs, rear, and calves all at the same time. Pick a platform, like a stair, bench, or footstool, that’s about 1 ft (0.30 m) off the ground. Stand up straight, then put your right foot on top of the platform. Push through your right foot to step up onto the platform, then lower back down for one rep. [9] X Research source Do 12 reps on each leg 3 times each. If you have bad knees, this exercise may not be for you. It can put pressure on your knee joints.

steps.title: This exercise also works your hip extensors.
steps.content: This exercise also works your hip extensors. Start by standing up straight with both feet underneath your hips. Step out to the side with your right foot, keeping your left foot in place. When your right foot hits the ground, bend your right knee to lower down into a squat position, keeping your left leg straight. Return to a standing position. [10] X Research source Do 10 to 12 reps on your right leg before you switch to your left leg. Try to do 3 to 4 sets of this exercise with a 30-second rest in between each one. You can increase the intensity of this exercise by holding a dumbbell or a medicine ball in front of your chest.

steps.title: You can do this exercise a few times a week.
steps.content: You can do this exercise a few times a week. Lie down on the floor, face-up, with your arms at your sides and palms down. Bend your knees up but keep your feet flat against the floor. Using your abs and glutes, raise your hips to form a straight line between your shoulders and knees, then hold the position for a few seconds. [11] X Research source Do 12 to 15 reps to complete 1 set. Try to do 2 to 3 sets at a time with a 30-second break in between each one. If you want to increase the intensity, hold a weight on the bony part of your hips (across your pelvis). Glute bridges are a popular exercise in pilates, so it may be worth trying a class to get a more comprehensive workout. steps.title: You don’t have to create a strict workout routine for stronger thighs.
steps.content: You don’t have to create a strict workout routine for stronger thighs. Instead, try taking the stairs instead of the elevator whenever you can to work your thighs, glutes, and calves. [12] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Taking the stairs can also elevate your heart rate, which is great for your heart health. If you don’t encounter stairs very often, try walking up a steep hill instead.

steps.title: It’s not only good for your thighs, but it’s also easy on your joints.
steps.content: It’s not only good for your thighs, but it’s also easy on your joints. You can either ride a stationary bike at your gym or in your home, or you can go for rides around your neighborhood as a fun way to get out of the house. [13] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Since cycling gets your heart rate up. It’s also a great cardio workout. If you have heart disease, arthritis, or thinning bones, get the okay from your doctor before you start riding a bike.

steps.title: This full-body workout will strengthen your thighs and the rest of your legs.
steps.content: This full-body workout will strengthen your thighs and the rest of your legs. As you kick through the water to propel your body forward, your thighs will shape up and get toned naturally. [14] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Try to head to the pool 3 to 5 times a week for 20 to 60 minutes each time. Many community centers have pools that are open to the public. Try holding onto a kickboard with your hands to target your legs.
